--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgo=
odwin@...> wrote:
>
> It is simple.
> 
> If you are using Python, do this:
=
> 
> If you have an object of class "BurnerFlame" (call it "b"), then
> 
> =
  b.gas returns the gas object used for the flame.
> 
> To set the gas obje=
ct to the state at grid point "j", do this:
> 
> b.setGasState(j)
> 
> Then=
 you can access mole fractions, etc., by commands like:
> 
> x =3D b.gas.mo=
leFraction()
> T =3D b.gas.temperature()
> 
> etc.
> 
> There is documentat=
ion that explains this. All you have to do in  
> Python is import the modu=
le you want help on:
> 
>  >>> from Cantera.OneD import BurnerFlame
> 
> an=
d then type:
> 
>  >>> help(BurnerFlame)
> 
> If you are using MATLAB, it i=
s not as easy, simply because the 
MATLAB  
> Cantera interface is not as f=
ully developed as the Python 
interface.   
> I would recommend running fla=
me simulations from Python for this 
reason.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> On Apr 23, 2=
007, at 11:41 PM, pavelyar wrote:
>

> >
> > Could any=
one please explain me how I can extract a gas 
composition out
> > of a fla=
me object?
> >

w I want 
to
> > model the hot products reacting on a Pt surface.
> >
> > C=
an I extract the hot products composition at some axial 
distance so
> > th=
at I could use those to create another gas object that will 
react on
> > a=
 catalytic surface (just like CH4/air mixture reacts in the 
catcomb
> > de=
mo)?

ps Links
